Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Social Environment and Nutrition in Female Monkeys

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social behavior influences an animal's ability to access foods that contain adequate nutrition for growth and reproduction. During the course of primate (including human) evolution, sociality was important for both preventing and helping individuals reach their nutritional goals when faced with competition from within their own species and other species. Consequently, the influence of sociality on nutrition, and vice versa, has implications for characterizing the evolution of human diet and for testing theories about primate socioecology. To explore these issues, this project will study sociality and nutrition in female redtail monkeys in Kibale National Park, Uganda. The broader impacts include training minority and female students in primate ecology and conservation, fostering international relationships and collaborations, and supporting public and student outreach about primate diversity and conservation.

This dissertation project will investigate the impact of sociality on the nutrition of female redtail monkeys (Cercopithecus ascanius). Females may face a tradeoff between (1) competition with other group members, potentially in the context of dominance hierarchies, and with other monkey species, and (2) their own nutritional goals. The investigators will examine the nutrient intake and balancing of females in three groups of monkeys within Kibale National Park. Macronutrient, energy and micronutrient intake, balance, and patterns of nutrient prioritization across females will be analyzed using the Geometric Framework (GF). The GF models how an animal balances multiple food components in relation to one another. These nutritional data will then be analyzed in the context of social behavior. This study will better characterize primate behavior, as well as niche construction among sympatric monkey species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Social behavior influences an individual’s nutrition and vice versa. An expansion of the social foraging concept, social nutrition involves a complex interaction between an animal’s physiology, behavior, and environment, an environment that includes nutritional components of foods as well as other foraging animals. Sociality was likely critical to both preventing and aiding individuals in reaching their nutritional goals, with fitness consequences, during the course of primate, including human, evolution. By making a social foraging question nutritionally explicit, we are also testing an aspect of the primate socioecological model and will contribute to understanding of the socioecology of an understudied living primate group (the guenons). To examine the effects of social environment on nutritional intake and balancing of a primate, we collected behavioral and nutritional data on adult females in three groups of redtail monkeys (Cercopithecus ascanius) in Kibale National Park, Uganda. Using the Geometric Framework of nutrition, we will examine daily nutritional intake and balance by individual females. Our preliminary results indicate that redtail monkey females maintain a daily ratio of non-protein energy:available protein (NPE:AP) of 7.8:1, a nutritional strategy between that previously reported for frugivorous and omnivorous primates. We will examine daily intake and NPE:AP balance by females across the three groups in relation to (1) changes in food availability, (2) the presence of other frugivorous monkey species, and (3) female social rank. We will also examine relationships between other nutrients, including minerals that have previously been correlated with redtail monkey abundance.

This project also provided substantial research and project management training to the co-PI, encouraged participation by minorities and women in STEM at the undergraduate level, as well as fostered collaborations across international institutions. Additionally, the co-PI worked with local communities in Uganda, training field assistants, teaching and offering instructor materials on conservation education at an elementary and middle school, as well as participating in a workshop with local children and elders to promote cross-generational communication about wildlife conservation.
